questions.text: Which of the following technique can be used for exact localization of a genetic locus?
questions.solution:
Gene mapping localizes specific genes to distinct chromosomes and thus define the map of human genome. This exact localization of genetic locus can be done by:

  1. Genetic linkage studies
  2. Somatic cell hybridization and
  3. In situ hybridization (More direct and simpler procedure done by adding radioactive probe to metaphase spread chromosome)

 

In Situ Hybridization (ISH)

This allows for precise localization of a specific segment of nucleic acid within a histologic section. The underlying basis of ISH is that nucleic acids, if preserved adequately within a histologic specimen, can be detected through the application of a complementary strand of nucleic acid to which a reporter molecule is attached.

 

In situ hybridization probes:

  1. Double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) probes
  2. Single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) probes
  3. RNA probes (riboprobes)
  4. Synthetic oligonucleotides (PNA, LNA)

Labelling techniques:

  • Radioactive isotopes
    • 32P
    • 35S
    • 3H
  • Non-radioactive labels
    • Biotin
    • Bigoxigenin
    • Fluorescent dye (FISH)

 

Rapid methods of chromosome identification:

  • FISH
  • Chromosome painting and
  • Spectral karyotyping (SKY)
  • FISH is a very sensitive technique which utilizes fluorescent probes
  • Chromosomal painting(CP) hybridizes multiple (coloured) fluorescent labeled DNA probes to chromosomal DNA. This produces a multicolored or painted effect with a unique color at each site of hybridization in metaphase or interphase cells. So CP identifies both numerical & structural chromosomal aberrations with high sensitivity and specificity.

choices.text: Nanocrystals have a narrow spectrum wavelength
Nanocrystals exhibit a narrow difference between their excitation and emission peak spectra

questions.text: Nanotechnology has found tremendous application in the diagnosis of cancers because of all of following advantages, except:
questions.solution:
• Nanocrystals (or Quantum dots) are inorganic semiconductor crystals which exhibit very bright (strong) photostable fluorescence emissions
  • They can be used as fluorescent probes in biological staining and diagnosis
  • The nanocrystals are more photochemically & optically stable (i.e. very durable)
  • Their electronic & optical properties (i.e. absorption band and emission spectra wavelength) can be adjusted by changing their size.

choices.text: Light attenuated in intensity by scattering

questions.text: Nephelometry is based on the principle of:
questions.solution:
• Nephelometry determines turbidity by measuring intensity of scattered light
  • When light passes through a medium with dispersed particles of different refractive indices, it is attenuated in intensity by scattering.
  • The intensity of scattered light depends on its wavelength & particle size.
  • Scattering is directly proportional to the concentration of particulate matter. This principle is used to measure turbidity by:
    1. Turbidimetry
    2. Nephelometry

questions.text: DNA fragments formed by the action of Restriction Endonucleases are separated by:
questions.solution: Gel electrophoresis is a technique used to separate DNA fragments (or other macromolecules, such as RNA and proteins) based on their size and charge. Electrophoresis involves running a current through a gel containing the molecules of interest. Based on their size and charge, the molecules will travel through the gel in different directions or at different speeds, allowing them to be separated from one another.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the most characteristic function of Type II Restriction Enzyme?
questions.solution:
Restriction endonucleases recognize short stretches of dsDNA (four to eight bp) that contain specific nucleotide sequences. These sequences, which differ for each restriction enzyme, are palindromes, that is, they exhibit twofold rotational symmetry. The restriction endonuclease makes 2 incisions through the phosphodiester bond of each strand of ds DNA at specific sequences known as recognition sequences or restriction site. Thus,  they produce smaller, manageable fragments with short sequences and sticky/blunt ends.  These restriction fragments can be isolated by agarose gel /polyacrylamide - electrophoresis or HPLC



There are three categories of restriction enzymes:

  1. Type I, which recognize specific DNA sequences but make their cut at seemingly random sites that can be as far as 1,000 base pairs away from the recognition site. EcoB and EcoK are type I enzymes
  2. Type II, which recognize and cut directly within the recognition site. HindII and HindIII are type II enzymes.
  3. Type III, which recognize specific sequences but make their cut at a different specific location that is usually within about 25 base pairs of the recognition site.

questions.text: For measurement of long DNA molecules (50-100KB), which of the following is used?
questions.solution:
• Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) is a difference in homologous DNA sequences (DNA sequence variation) that can be detected by the presence of fragments of different lengths after digestion of the DNA samples with specific restriction endonucleases.

 

  • These restriction fragments are separated by agarose gel electrophoresis on the basis of size and detected by southern blot


  • RFLP results from single nucleotide polymorphism (SNPs), single base changes (mutation), deletions, insertions (copy number variations = CNVs), length polymorphism / variable number of tandem repeals (VNTR), like mini satellite repeats and microsatellite or short tandem repeats (STR), All of these result in gain / loss of a restriction site thereby producing extra fragments.

 

  • RFLP is used for identification of gene for genomic mapping, establishing linkage (thus analyzing chromosomal structure and measurement /identification of DNA fragments or molecules of different sire), which baptism of chromosome walking will eventually define disease locus and isolate any gene in unknown location of large DNA.

questions.text: Microsatellite sequence is:
questions.solution:
MICROSATELLITE:

  • Tandem repeat sequences of 2 to 5 bp repeated up to 50 times. May occur at 50 to 100 thousand locations in the genome
  • Microsatellite instability  involves expansion or contraction of microsatellite DNA sequences, usually due to abnormalities of mismatch repair or replication slippage

 

LOOPED-DNA:

  • A DNA loop is formed when a protein or a complex of proteins simultaneously binds to two different sites on DNA.
  • Depending on the location of the proteins relative to the transcriptional start site, the formation of the DNA loop can be responsible for transcriptional repression or for transcriptional activation.

questions.text: DNA fingerprinting is based on:
questions.solution:
• DNA Fingerprinting is the use of RFLPs or repeat sequence DNA(VNTR) to establish a unique pattern of DNA fragments for an individual.
  • Variable Number Tandem Repeats (VNTR) is unique for any individual. Therefore, it serves as Molecular DNA fingerprint. VNTR may be:
    • Short tandem (microsatellite) or
    • Large tandem (minisatellite) repeats

choices.text: Annealing is done after DNA denaturation
Requires atleast 1 week's time for synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about PCR?
questions.solution:
Polymerase Chain Reaction PCR)

  • PCR is an enzymatic method for the repeated copying (and thus amplification) of the two strands of DNA that make up a particular gene sequence.
  • Each cycle of heat denaturation separation /melting) + priming (annealing) − polymerization, doubles the amount double stranded DNA with each cycle. PCR uses a pair of primers

questions.text: All of the following are DNA Amplification techniques except:
questions.solution:
DNA amplification techniques are known as nucleic acid amplification test (NAATs).

These include:

  1. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
  2. Real time PCR
  3. Ligase chain reaction (LCR)
  4. Gap LCR
  5. Nucleic acid sequence based amplification (NASBA)
  6. strand displacement amplification
  7. multiple displacement amplification
  8. Loop-mediated isothermal amplification

Clinical use of NAA:

Nucleic acid amplification assays (NAAs) amplify and detect organisms such as Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrheae, Mycobacterium tuberculosis from relevant samples.

 

Two U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved NAAs are available to amplify and detect M. tuberculosis–specific nucleic acid sequences in clinical specimens within 24 to 48 hours:

  1. AMPLICOR M. tuberculosis
  2. Amplified Mycobacterium Tuberculosis Direct (MTD) Test

choices.text: Hybridoma cell produced by fusion of T - cell & myeloma

questions.text: All are true about Hybridoma except:
questions.solution:
HYVRIDOMA

  • Hybridoma cells result from the fusion of B lymphocytes and myeloma cells  and are used to produce specific monoclonal antibodies. 
  • B cells that are previously immunized or injected with antigen are fused with myeloma cells of mouse (or suitable animal) to produce the Hybridoma cell which is an immortal cell.
  • Hybridomas possess two important properties of B cells:
  1. Production of antibodies and 
  2. Immortalization of myeloma cells
  • Monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) are monospecific antibodies that are produced by a clone of B cells

Interesting Trivia: 

hYBRIDOMA technology was invented by Cesar Milstein and Georges J. F. Kohler in 1975. For this invention, they received the Nobel Prize for Medicine and Physiology with Niels Kaj Jerne in 1984.

questions.text: Northern blot is used for the separation of:
questions.solution:
Blotting techniques:

  1. Fragments are separated on the basis of their mass (size in Daltons or kiloDaltons kD) by agarose or SDS- polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE)
  2. The pattern is then transferred to nitrocellulose /nylon paper (blotting or adsorption)
  3. Then probe is  added  - complementing, hybridizing & detecting the desired fragment. Probes may be labelled using enzyme/radioactive/or fluorescent molecules

 

  • Southern blotting, Northern blotting and Western blotting techniques are used respectively to analyze DNA, mRNA and proteins in samples. The probes used in these techniques are c-DNA, CDNA and antibody respectively.

choices.text: Library that contains books on gene
Computers base with all gene knowledge
Complete collection of gene copies of one organism

questions.text: True about gene library:
questions.solution:
• Genomic DNA (gene) library contain a copy of every DNA nucleotide sequence in genome
  • c-DNA (gene) libraries contain those DNA sequences that transcribe as mRNA

questions.text: Techniques used for protein expression and analysis in proteomics include all except:
questions.solution:
• Study of structure & products of gene is genomics
  • Study of multiplication of proteins in disease process is called proteomic Two dimensional electrophoresis, gene arrays (DNA chips), multidimensional protein identification technology (Mud PIT) employing successive rounds of chromatography are used to survey protein expression in proteomics.
  • After 2D electrophoresis, individual polypeptides are extracted and analyzed by Edman sequencing or mass spectroscopy
  • Protein purity is most widely assessed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) - SDS (sodium dodecyl sulfate).

questions.text: Which of the following molecular phenomenon in Ig gene is responsible for affinity maturation of antibody response?
questions.solution:
• Affinity Maturation refers to the increased affinity of antibodies for their specific antigen as the antibody response continues.
  • Those B-cells expressing receptors with a higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded, even as the levels of antigen fall. Thus B-cells with higher affinity are generated during the 1° & 2° immune responses in large part due to Somatic hypermutations that occur in VH genes (VH=Variable region of Heavy chain).
  • This phenomenon is not seen in IgM responses

questions.text: An Immunoglobulin molecule represents the following level of organized protein structure:
questions.solution:
• Quaternary structure of protein refers to three dimensional arrangements of these protein subunits. Therefore, homo-or hetero-dimers formed between 2 polypeptide chains is an example of quaternary structure. Similarly, an immunoglobin molecule represents hetero-tetrameric quaternary structure between 4 polypeptides (2 heavy + 2 light) chains.
  • Secondary and tertiary structures of protein maintain the 3- dimensional shape of protein and the main bonds involved are weak non-covalent bonds

 

Structural Organization of Protein

questions.text: Keratin in skin is softer than keratin in nail because keratin in skin has:
questions.solution:
• Keratin in skin is softer than keratin in nail, horn and hooves because skin keratin has less number of disulfide bonds between Cys residues of adjacent polypeptide chains.
  • Keratin contains Histidine, Arginine & Lysine

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids in a protein commonly acts as a potential O-Glycosylation site for attachment of an oligosaccharide unit?
questions.solution:
• O-glycosylation involves addition of a specific oligosaccharide unit (sugar chain) to the terminal (OH) group of serine or threonine (commonly) and tyrosine, hydroxylysine or hydroxyproline (rarely). Glycosyl transferase responsible for O-glycosylation is found in Golgi complex
  • Dolichol synthesis, glycosyl transferase and protein oligosaccharide transferase steps of N-glycosylation occur in endoplasmic reticulum (ER).

questions.text: Protein that precipitates on heating to 45° C and redissolves on boiling is:
questions.solution:
• Bence Jones protein in urine can be identified by its characteristic property of coagulation (precipitation or clumping due to denaturation) when heated to 50 - 60 C. But the clumps begin to disappear (due to renaturation) when the sample is further heated to boiling point (70 - 100'C) Again on cooling, clumps reappear (Heat test). 
  • Cryoglobulins (immunoglobulin proteins) precipitate when cooled and dissolve on heating to higher temperatures
  • Pyroglobulins (associated with multiple myeloma, macroglobulinemia & other neoplastic disorders) resembles Bence Jones proteins in that both precipitate on heating to about 50°C but do not dissolve when cooled.

questions.text: False positive test of protein in dipstick test seen in:
In a particular method of chromatography, molecules that are negatively charged are selectively released from stationary phase into the positively charged molecules in mobile phase. This method is:
questions.solution:
• In cation exchange chromatography, solid stationary matrix has negatively charged groups (i.e. negatively charged carboxy methyl cellulose is used as cation exchanger).
  • So, in the mobile phase, proteins with a net positive charge (i.e. cations) move slowly than those with net negative charge (anion). Hence aspartate (aspartic acid) being a negatively charged amino acid will move fastest in carboxymethyl cellulose or methanol chloroform (cation exchanger) ion exchange chromatography

questions.text: Substance which binds to substrate other than catalytic enzyme is-
questions.solution:
In non-competitive inhibition, there is no competition between substrate & inhibitor because inhibitor is structurally different and it binds to enzyme at a site other than substrate binding (catalytic) site,

 

INHIBITOR(I): Any substance that can decrease the velocity of an enzyme catalysed reaction

  • The inhibition can be:
    • Reversible or
    • Irreversible.

Reversible inhibitors bind to enzymes through non-covalent bonds and can be dissociated from its binding site by dilution, without losing its enzyme activity.

  • Two most common types of reversible inhibition are competitive & non-competitive. However, the non-competitive can also be irreversible.

Irreversible inhibitors bind to enzyme through covalent bonds and can be removed from its site of binding only at the loss of enzymatic activity (Le. irreversible inhibitors poison enzymes).

Non-Competitive Inhibition:

  • Reversible or irreversible
  • Bear no (or little) structure resemblance to substrate
  • Inhibitors bind enzymes at sites distinct from substrate binding site (i.e. substrate (S) and inhibitor (=I) bind enzyme (=E) at different sites). Therefore, there is no competition between inhibitor & substrate for enzyme.
  • Inhibitor can bind to ES complex
  • Same amount of substrate is needed to achieve 1/2 Vmax (i.e. Km is unaffected)

choices.text: Substrate concentration of one third Vmax

questions.text: Km value is defined as:
questions.solution:
• Km: The Michaelis constant Km is the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is equal to ½ Vmax. Therefore, it measures specificity of substrate for enzyme

Enzymatic inhibition:

  1. Competitive:
    • Km is increased
    • Vmax is unchanged
  2. Non competitive:
    • Km is unchanged
    • Vmax is decreased

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are regulated by calcium or calmodulin, except:
questions.solution:
• Phosphorylation is the most important type of regulatory modification
  • It involves addition or removal of phosphate group from serine, threonine, tyrosine or histidine residue of enzyme
  • ATP is used as PO4(phosphate) donor
  • Protein kinase enzyme catalyzes phosphorylation (i.e addition of PO4,) and Phosphoprotein phosphatase catalyzes dephosphorylation (i.e. removal of PO4 group).

choices.text: Same enzyme classification with same umbers

questions.text: True about isoenzymes is:
questions.solution:
• Isozymes (iso enzymes) catalyze the same reaction but at different rates. They differ from each other in three ways:
    1. Structurally due to difference in quaternary structure
    2. Electrophoretically due to different number of charged acidic or basic amino acids
    3. Physically i.e. in physical properties such as heat resistance due to genetically determined differences in amino acid sequence.

They differ in pH optima, Km and Vmax values as well as in enzymatic classification numbers. Isoenzymes have different tissue distributions.

  • Isoenzyme LDH-1 with four 'H' subunit predominates in cardiac tissue, since heart expresses the H subunit almost exclusively.

questions.text: Selenium is co-factor for:
questions.solution:
• Selenium in form of selenocysteine is a component (as a prosthetic group) of
  1. Glutathione peroxidase
  2. Thioredoxin and
  3. Deiodinase that converts thyroxine to tri-iodo-thyronine
  • Selenium deficiency causes:
    • Keshan disease (endemic cardiomyopathy)
    • Kashin–Beck Disease (KBD) endemic degenerative osteoarthritis or osteopathy particularly affecting children
  • Low selenium levels also increase the risk of thrombotic episode, cancer (specially GI, more so oesophegeal & orolaryngeal cancers). Concomitant deficiency of Se and iodine may worsen clinical manifestations of cretinism.

questions.text: Abzyme is a/an
questions.solution:
• Abenzymes are catalytic antibodies + enzyme
  • Also called as catalytic antibody or catmab
  • It is an antibody harboring catalytic potential
  • While antibodies with catalytic activity can be generated in the laboratory, abzymesare also found in healthy individuals and in patients with >lupus and other autoimmune diseases in whom they may recognize and then hydrolyze DNA  antigens. 
  • They may have important functional roles in homeostasis, autoimmune diseases, and in protection against infection

questions.text: Glutamine in blood acts as:
questions.solution:
• Glutamine is the sole form of transport of ammonia in brain
  • Glutamine is an amide of glutamic acid which is formed from alpha – Ketoglutarate. (products of TCA cycle).
  • Ammonia is transported to liver from peripheral tissue for its ultimate conversion to urea. Two mechanisms are available in humans for this transport:

 

TRANSPORT OF AMMONIA TO LIVER



As Glutamine

  • Provides a non-toxic storage & transport from of NH3Q
  • Major mechanism for removal of NH3 in brain
  • Formation of glutamine from glutamate and NH3 occurs primarily in muscle and liver
  • Glutamine is an amide of glutamic acid (glutamate which is formed from Alpha- Ketoglutarate

questions.text: Ammonia is detoxified (removed as) in brain to:
A child present with metabolic lactic acidosis along with hyperammonemia and convulsion is due to:
questions.solution:
• Urea cycle defect (only hyperammonemia seen, no lactic acidosis, no convulsions) amd Phenylketonuria can be easily ruled out. There is confusion between MELAS & Reye's syndrome.

MELAS (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis & Stroke like episodes):

Children with MELAS may be normal for the first several years, but they gradually display delayed motor and cognitive development and short stature. The clinical syndrome is characterized by:

  • Recurrent stroke like episodes manifesting as hemiparesis, hemianopia or cortical blindness.
  • Lactic acidosis, ragged red fibres or both
  • At least two of the following:
    • focal or generalized
    • seizures
    • dementia
    • recurrent migraine headaches

 

Reye's Syndrome

(Syndrome of acute encephalopathy and fatty degeneration of liver)

  • Aspirin or salicylates used for certain viral respiratory infections might precipitate Reye's syndrome.
  • The major site of injury is the mitochondria.
  • The activities of hepatic intramitochondrial enzymes, involving Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC), Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase (CPS) and pyruvate dehydrogenase are
    • Hyperammonemia may result from decreased activities of OTC and CPS.
    • Lactic acidosis results from decreased activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • Clinical features:
  • Biphasic course. It usually occurs in a previously healthy child.
  1. A prodromal febrile illness, an upper respiratory tract infections or chicken pox is followed by an interval in which the child has seemingly recovered.
  2. 5-7 days later there is abrupt onset of symptoms - Vomiting, irrational behaviour, seizures, stupor & coma.

 

  • Laboratory features:
    • CSF- is normal except for elevated pressure
    • Hyperammonemia
    • Respiratory and metabolic acidosis Features of hepatic failure
    • Increase AST, Increase ALT, Increase LDH, Increase PT
    • The striking and characteristic gross pathological feature of Reye’s syndrome is a yellow to white liver, reflective of high content of triglycerides. There is microvescicular fatty steatosis of liver, kidney and brain.
    • Brain shows gross cerebral edema.

questions.text: Tryptophan is glucogenic and Ketogenic by Producing:
questions.solution:
TRYPTOPHAN

  • Precursor of niacin and serotonin
    • 60mg tryptophan give rise to 1mg Niacin
    • Serotonin forms melatonin
  • Tryptophan is glucogenic (by producing alanine) & ketogenic (by producing acetyl CoA)

questions.text: Aromatic rings is present in all the amino acids except:
questions.solution: • The property of photo-chromicity is due to absorbance of ultraviolet light at 250-290nm is seen with aromatic amino acid (tryptophan > tyrosine > phenylalanine).

questions.text: Amino acid with double chiral is:
questions.solution: • Threonine & isoleucine  have 2 chiral centers (double chirality)

questions.text: Vitamin involved in 1-carbon metabolism:
questions.solution:
One Carbon Units

  • One carbon unit can exist in the form of methane, methanol, formaldehyde, formic acid and carbonic acid, all of which except methane can be incorporated in various synthetic pathways.

 

  • Sources of one carbon unit are:
    1. Serine
    2. Glycine
    3. Choline
    4. Histidine, and
    5. Formates

 

  • Carriers of One carbon units:
    1. Tetrahydrofolate and
    2. S-adenosyl methionine(SAM)

questions.text: PKU is a congenital amino acid metabolic disorder. In one of the following rare variants of PKU, DihydroBiopterin synthesis is affected. The enzyme deficient is:
questions.solution:
• Phenylalanine gets converted to Tyrosine (Phe to Tyr) by a hydroxylating system consisting of:
    • PhenylAlanine Hydroxylase (PAH)
    • The unconjugated pterin cofactor, tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)
    • Enzymes which serve to regenerate BH4, namely dihydropteridine reductase and 4α-carbinolamine dehydratase
  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive inborn error of phenylalanine (Phe) metabolism resulting from:
    • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH); mutations in the PAHgene on chromosome 12q23
    • Defects in the synthesis/regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin(Dihydropterin reductase
  • Phenylalanine accumulates, and is converted to compounds such as the phenylketones, which give the urine a musty odor

questions.text: A 40-year old woman presented with progressive palmoplantar pigmentation. X - ray spine showed calcification of intervertebral discs. On adding Benedicts regent to urine, it gives a greenish brown precipitate and blue-black supernatant fluid. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ALKAPTONURIA:

  • It is due to defective homogentisate 1, 2-dioxygenase (defective tyrosine degradation)
  • Usually presents after the age of 40 with characteristic triad of:
    1. Homogentisic aciduria (Urine which blackens/darkens on exposure to air and is strongly Benedict's positive) Image 1
    2. Ochronosis (i.e black pigmentation of cartilage & collagenous connective tissue) Image 2
    3. Arthritis of large joints

questions.text: In hemoglobin, iron is bound to:
questions.solution:
• Hemoglobin has 4 polypeptide chains: two identical Alpha – chain and two identical β chains
  • Iron (Fe2+) of Hb IS bound to histidine & four pyrrole rings

choices.text: Binding of O2 causes release of H2
One mole of deoxyhemoglobin binds two moles of 2,3 DPG
pH of blood has no affect on the binding of O2
Binding of O2 cause increased binding of 2,3 DPG

questions.text: True regarding conversion of deoxyhemoglobin to oxyhemoglobin is:
questions.solution:
• Binding of O2­ to deoxyhemoglobin in lungs causes release of proton (H+). this is responsible for Bohr effect
  • 2,3 – DPG is produced by an alternative pathway in glycolysis. It is formed from 3- phosphoglyceraldehyde, which is a product of glycolysis via Emdben – MeyerhofF pathway.
  • It is abundant in RBCs
  • If the glycolytic activity is decreased, the level of 2,3-DPG in RBCs will decrease.
  • Decreased level of 2,3 DPG results in:
    • Left Shift of the O2 HB curve to left
    • Increases the O2 affinity of Hb­ (impairs O­2 transport)

questions.text: The enzyme deficient in erythropoietic porphyria is:
questions.solution:
• Erythropoietic protoporphyria is due to deficiency of enzyme ferrochelatase
  • All porphyrias are autosomal dominant (AD) except:
    • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (autosomal recessive, AR)
    • ALA dehydratase (porphobilinogen) deficiency (AR) and
    • X – linked protoporphyria (x-linked)

choices.text: Decreased levels of fructose in the blood
Elevated levels of glyceraldehyde in liver cells
High levels of sucrose in the stool
Elevated levels of fructose-1-phosphate in liver cells

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl has been a fussy eater since being weaned, particularly when fruit is part of her diet. She would get cranky, sweaty, and display dizziness and lethargy after eating a meal with fruit. Her mother noticed this correlation and as long as fruit was withdrawn from her diet, the child did not display such symptoms. The problems the girl exhibits when eating fruit is most likely due to which one of the following?
questions.solution:
The patient has Hereditary Fructose Intolerance(HFI) which is due to a mutation in aldolase B.

  • Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is a recessively inherited inborn error of metabolism due to deficiency of fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase enzyme activity (Aldolase B), an enzyme of fructose-1-phosphate metabolism
  • In this condition, ingestion of fructose leads to toxic effects on the liver, intestines, and kidney.
    • Acute ingestion can cause hypoglycemia and gastrointestinal symptoms
    • Chronic ingestion can lead to hepatic or renal injury and growth disturbance

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant was cranky and irritable, became quite lethargic between feedings, and began to develop a potbelly. A physical exam demonstrated an enlarged liver, while blood work taken between feedings demonstrated elevated lactate and uric acid levels, as well as hypoglycemia. This child most likely has a mutation in which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
• The child has the symptoms of von Gierke’s disease, which is due to a lack of glucose 6-phosphatase
  • In this disorder, neither liver glycogen nor gluconeogenic precursors (e.g., alanine and glycerol) can be used to maintain normal blood glucose levels.
  • The last step (conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose) is deficient for both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Muscle glycogen cannot be used to maintain blood glucose levels because muscle does not contain glucose 6-phosphatase.
  • A defective liver glycogen phosphorylase (Her’s disease) will not affect the ability of the liver to raise blood glucose levels by gluconeogenesis.
  • In addition, the lack of liver glycogen phosphorylase does not lead to lactic and uric acid accumulation, although mild fasting hypoglycemia can be observed. Defects in liver glycogen synthase (type 0 glycogen storage disease) will lead to an early death, with hypoglycemia and hyperketonemia observed. Muscle does not contribute to blood glucose levels, so a defect in muscle glycogen phosphorylase (McArdle’s disease) will not lead to the observed symptoms, but will lead to exercise intolerance. A defect in pyruvate kinase will lead to hemolytic anemia, but not the other symptoms observed in the patient.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with Type 2 diabetes is taking glipizide to help control his blood sugar levels. One day, he could not remember if he had taken the medication, so he accidently took a second dose of the drug. Two hours later, he suddenly develops irritability, tremors, tachycardia, and lightheadedness. In response to the overdose of glipizide, the patient has released hormones that will lead to glucose being released by the liver. This occurs through an initial activation of which one of the following liver enzymes?
questions.solution:
• The patient has become hypoglycemic due to excessive release of insulin from the pancreas. Glipizide is a sulfonylurea drug that stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.
  • If taken in excess, the insulin will promote fat and muscle cells to take up glucose from the circulation, leading to hypoglycemia and insufficient blood glucose levels for normal brain function. Lactic acidosis may result from such an overdose, but it would be secondary to the hypoglycemic symptoms observed.
  • Elevated ammonia levels would not occur, as glipizide does not alter amino acid metabolism. The high levels of insulin released by the drug would inhibit fatty acid release from the adipocytes, and therefore the precursors for ketone body synthesis are not available, and ketoacidosis would not occur. The patient is having a hypoglycemic attack. Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin release from the pancreas and can cause hypoglycemia. Glucagon, epinephrine, and glucocorticosteroids are all released to raise blood glucose levels. The symptoms observed in the patient are side effects of epinephrine, acting in the autonomic nervous system.
  • Epinephrine, via binding to its receptor, activates a Gs-protein, which binds to and activates adenylate cyclase. Adenylate cyclase will convert ATP to cAMP.
  • As cAMP levels increase, the cAMP binds to the regulatory subunits of protein kinase A, allowing the regulatory subunits to be released from the catalytic subunits. This activates protein kinase A, which then phosphorylates both glycogen synthase and phosphorylase kinase.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by phosphorylation by phosphorylase kinase. Thus, of the events listed, activation of adenylate cyclase is the initial event

questions.text: Dietary supplementation of which one of the following would be beneficial to a child with primary carnitine deficiency patient?
questions.solution:
• Primary carnitine deficiency is an autosomal recessive Carnitine is required to transfer most fatty acids from the cytoplasm to the matrix of the mitochondria. Patients with primary carnitine deficiency can only metabolize medium-chain fatty acids.
  • Coconut oil is high in medium-chain saturated fatty acids.
  • Dietary restriction of long-chain fatty acids is essential to treat this disorder and alleviate the symptoms
  • In many cases of primary carnitine deficiency, increasing the blood levels of carnitine is sufficient to allow some transport of carnitine into cells such that fatty acid oxidation can occur. While pantothenic acid (part of coenzyme A), niacin (the precursor for NAD1), and riboflavin (needed for FAD) are required for fatty acid oxidation, the rate-limiting step in these patients is the transport of the fatty acids from the cellular cytoplasm to the matrix of the mitochondria.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man, after suffering a heart attack, was put on 81 mg of aspirin daily by his cardiologist. The purpose of this treatment is to reduce the levels of which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Platelet aggregation is often a determining factor in heart attacks. Thromboxane A2, produced by platelets, promotes platelet aggregation when clotting is required, and inhibition of thromboxane A2 synthesis by aspirin reduces the potential for inappropriate clot formation, and further heart attacks.
  • Thromboxane A2 is produced from arachidonic acid by the action of cyclooxygenase. This enzyme covalently modified and irreversibly inhibited by aspirin.
  • Leukotrienes are also synthesized from arachidonic acid, but utilize lipoxygenase in their synthesis, which is not inhibited by aspirin.
  • Cholesterol, triglyceride, and cytokine synthesis do not require cyclooxygenase activity.

questions.text: A reduction in the metabolism of which one of the following amino acids can lead to elevated homocysteine levels in the blood?
questions.solution:
• Methionine, obtained from the diet, is activated by the reaction with ATP to form SAM, the universal methyl donor. After donating a methyl group, SAM is converted to S-adenosylhomocysteine. A hydrolase removes the adenosine, generating homocysteine.
  • Homocysteine then has two fates:
    • It can react with N5-methyl-FH4 (with B12) to regenerate methionine
    • It can react with serine (in the presence of B6) to form cystathionine, which goes on to form cysteine.

A defect in either the enzyme that forms methionine (methionine synthase) or the enzyme that forms cystathionine (cystathionine b-synthase) will lead to elevated homocysteine levels

 

  • High homocysteine levels may be a risk factor for early atherosclerotic disease. The high levels appear to be associated with low B6, B12, and/or folate levels. Vitamin B12 is required for the methionine synthase reaction (homocysteine 1 N5-methyl-FH4 yields methionine and FH4), vitamin B6 is required for the cystathionine s-synthase reaction (homocysteine 1 serine yields cystathionine), and folate is required for the methionine synthase reaction. Vitamins B3 (niacin), C, E, and B1 (thiamine) are not required for homocysteine metabolism

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has had episodic periods during which areas of his skin would develop a rash, which would spontaneously resolve in a week to 10 days. An astute pediatrician told the boy's parents to give him niacin the next time this occurred and a high-protein diet, and when they did, the rash resolved in a day or two. A likely disorder that this child has is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
HARTNUP DISEASE:

  • Hartnup disease is a transport defect, manifesting in both the kidney and intestinal epithelial cells. The transporter is for large, neutral amino acids
  • Tryptophan uptake can be limit with this disorder. Under such conditions, the body may not produce sufficient NAD for its needs (the nicotinamide ring can be produced from dietary niacin, as well as tryptophan), and a pellagra-like illness can develop.
  • Giving the child niacin will allow the NAD to be regenerated, and a high-protein diet may increase tryptophan levels such that the transporter can transport tryptophan from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.
  • Cystinuria is a different transport defect that does not allow cystine to be absorbed from the diet, or removed from the urine. Cystine is returned to the blood in the kidney (which can give rise to kidney stones).
  • Myasthenia gravis is due to autoantibodies directed against the acetylcholine receptor.
  • Alkaptonuria is due to a defect in homogentisic acid oxidase

questions.text: Which of the following components of respiratory oxidative phosphorylation is correctly matched with its inhibitors?
questions.solution: Inhibitors of Oxidative Phosphorylation:

questions.text: All of the following are endogenous sources of ROS within the cell except:
questions.solution:
Major sources of primary ROS in the cell:

  • Coenzyme Q generates superoxide as a by-product of the electron transport chain
  • Oxidases, oxygenases, and peroxidases
  • Cytochrome P450 enzymes are a major source of free radicals leaked from reactions.
  • Hydrogen peroxide and lipid peroxides are generated enzymatically as reaction products in peroxisomes, mitochondria, and the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • Ionizing radiation splits water into hydroxyl and hydrogen radicals, leading to radiation damage to the skin, DNA base alterations, cancer, and cell death.

 

SuperOxide Dismutase(SOD) forms the first line of defense against ROS-induced damages

questions.text: Disease X has been linked to the creation of a new restriction enzyme site, as indicated in the associated figure. The relevant area of the DNA is shown, along with EcoR1 restriction sites, sizes of fragments obtained, and an area to which a probe is available (the small red box). A family has had DNA obtained to determine if they are carriers for this disorder, and their DNA was digested with EcoR1, and a Southern blot was done using the available probe. A carrier for this disorder would display which bands on the Southern blot?
questions.solution:
• Carrier would have one normal allele (which would generate a 3.0-kb EcoR1 fragment), and one mutated allele (which generates fragments of 1.1 and 1.9 kb). The key to answering this question is that the probe is located within the 1.1-kb fragment that is generated in the mutant allele (it is also within the normal 3.0-kb fragment generated from the normal allele).
  • So when the Southern blot is probed with the given probe, only the 1.1-kb piece of DNA will anneal to the probe and be visible in the mutated allele.
  • Since this section of DNA is also present in the 3.0-kb piece of DNA, a 3.0-kb piece of DNA will also be visible on the Southern blot.
  • If the person had two normal alleles, then only the 3.0-kb piece would be visible–if the person had the disease, then only the 1.1-kb piece would be visible on the Southern blot.

questions.text: All of the following are lysosomal storage disorders except:
questions.solution: I-cell disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by a mutation in the GNPTA gene that leads to a deficiency in the enzyme UDP-N-acetylglucoseamine-1-phosphotransferase. I-cell disease is inherited as an autosomal recessive genetic trait.
